channel.title: Tom Stemberg
channel.description: Tom Stemberg (Remarks as Prepared for Delivery)

item.title: Twenty-five years ago I had a crazy idea for a new business.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: I wanted to do to office supplies what Home Depot had done with home improvement. I pictured an office superstore for regular customers and small businesses. The business would be called Staples.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: It wasn't easy at first. I had a vision and a business plan.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Then I met Mitt Romney. He helped make it come alive.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Now Mitt was an unusual guy. He had already enjoyed great success at Bain & Company. But he knew the value of a dollar.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: When I told him about Staples, he really got excited at the idea of saving a few cents on paper clips.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Funny thing.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: But I ask you. Who would make a better president: Someone who knows how to save a dollar on pens and paper or someone who knows how to waste $535 million on Solyndra?
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: The truth is Mitt was not a typical investor. He was a true partner. Where some saw an unproven new business, he saw a store that could save people money. He recognized that efficiency creates consumer value.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: He never looked at Staples as merely a financial investment. He saw the engine of prosperity it could become.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Today Staples employs nearly 90,000 people. It has over 2,000 stores. Over 50 distribution centers. It is part of a competitive industry that helps entrepreneurs and small businesses get started on their own. For me, as a founder, it was the realization of a dream.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: So you can imagine my dismay, when I see this White House and their campaign demonizing Mitt Romney. Demonizing Bain Capital. Demonizing the private equity industry that created so many new jobs.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Over and over again: Fiction. Half truths. Down-right lies.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: You have to ask yourself: why would an Administration that can't create any jobs demonize someone who did?
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: I've got a theory.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: I think when it comes to jobs, new businesses, and economic growth ­ they just don't get it.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: They say that Mitt Romney is out of touch with ordinary Americans.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: They just don't get it.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: The night before we opened the first store, I asked our people to do back-to-back all-nighters.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: That's when I got a call from Mitt. He wanted to come over and talk with the team, spend time with them. He told me in very clear terms: This business is all about the people.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: But this Obama-Biden campaign; they just don't get it.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: They will tell you that private equity is focused only on the short-term.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Tell that to the founders of Bright Horizons Day Care, a company that has transformed corporate day care.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Most people didn't give the business a chance. It went for five straight years without making a profit ­ but Mitt and Bain Capital stood by them.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Mitt and Bain Capital believed in the vision.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: They understood how important it was for women to join the workforce and have on-site care for their children. It was an overdue revolution in the American workplace.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Today the company employs over 19,000 people.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: But President Obama and his friends, they just don't get it.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: The Obama campaign will tell you that Bain Capital was a form of "Vampire Capitalism." Drain the blood from a company and move on. They just don't get it.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Where were they when Mitt stayed with Staples for 15 years ­ long after Bain Capital had sold its stock?
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Where were they when Bain Capital helped start Steel Dynamics, when most people had given up on the American steel industry?
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Eighteen years later that company employs 6,000 people.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: But this administration they just don't get it.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: They've got a Jobs Council that never meets.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: A Democratic Senate that doesn't act.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: A President who doesn't believe and a Vice President who won't stop talking.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: They just don't get it.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: They don't get it because they don't believe in the spirit of the entrepreneur. They don't understand what it means to risk money to create something new.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: They don't understand the hard work it takes to get a business off the ground. The sacrifices you make, the Little League games you miss.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: They don't see that this is a country of opportunity, where someone like myself, the son of immigrants born in Newark, New Jersey ­ and proud of it, Governor Christie ­ can live the American dream.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: Well, let me tell you: my friend Mitt Romney gets it.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: And I could not be more confident in saying that the American people get it.
item.author: Tom Stemberg

item.title: That's why, this November, they will elect Mitt Romney as the next President of the United States of America.
item.author: Tom Stemberg
